posts.cooked: This creeping surveillance threat of Chat Control is an endless agony. Itâ€™s not enough for it to not pass, it must not be even proposed again.

With authoritarianismâ€™s grip on European politics getting firmer and firmer Iâ€™m not optimisticâ€¦

Itâ€™s a real embarrassment, that Europe needs to be told this by an organisation based in Trumpland, of all places.

eu is not only country which introduced horrible laws. many countries have introduced and some cases passed some horrible laws. most of these countries are democratic and free.

i donâ€™t think this will pass. but getting this close is terrifying. there will be something annoying in the future again, and not just limited to eu.

iâ€™m afraid this might become a theme worldwide, in which every area in this planet has some annoying thing or other.

this may not be one hurdle, this might be constant long term annoyance for years.
Hm, now that Iâ€™m thinking about it: might as well start using WeChat if this passes. Does anybody know if itâ€™s any good?

posts.name: MixusMinimax
posts.cooked: we not only need a proposal like this to not pass, even more, we need a counter-proposal. We need to strengthen the GDPR. We need to make a law that makes something like chat control completely illegal and impossible to be proposed again.
Such as the European Convention on Human Rights?

Thereâ€™s Backdoors that let cops decrypt messages violate human rights, EU court says - Ars Technica but member states simply ignore it like they have been doing with data retention. Donâ€™t count on GDPR because that was made to regulate data sharing and hurt US companies, not protect agains government surveillance.

link_counts.title: Backdoors that let cops decrypt messages violate human rights, EU court says - Ars Technica

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: and letâ€™s not forget that a bunch of countries want to leave the ECHR because it doesnâ€™t let them be as mean to migrants as they wish to beâ€¦

and hurt US companies,

bullshit!
gpdr does not differentiate based on country of origin or anything else!

Itâ€™s not BS, obviously GDPR by statue applies to everyone but in practice:

  1. States can and easily do violate GDPR by simply creating a law legitimizing data collection

  2. due to EU always losing ground on tech innovation, GDPR is also a way to put annoyances and costs on US competitor platforms, though unsuccessfully

  3. despite this, GDPR is still good
No it is not any more - it is just a poster now!
